meanings.definition: Remove matter thought to be objectionable or unsuitable from (a book or account)
meanings.sent1: The teacher had to expurgate the inappropriate content from the student's essay.
meanings.sent2: The editor decided to expurgate the offensive language from the article.
meanings.sent3: The librarian had to expurgate the book before it could be placed in the children's section.
meanings.sent4: She carefully expurgated the sensitive information from the document before sharing it.
meanings.sent5: In order to protect the audience, the director had to expurgate the violent scenes from the movie.

meanings.definition: Censor (a book or account) by removing or changing content
meanings.sent1: The government decided to expurgate the controversial paragraphs from the report.
meanings.sent2: The publisher had to expurgate the explicit scenes from the novel before it could be released.
meanings.sent3: The editor jokingly said he would expurgate all the boring parts of the manuscript.
meanings.sent4: She felt like she had to expurgate her social media posts to maintain a professional image.
meanings.sent5: The artist had to expurgate some of the artwork to comply with the gallery's guidelines.
